sec.title: Organizations supporting ex-offenders in the community
sec.p: Works for Freedom is a website highlighting organizations that provide support in different ways to, for example, serving prisoners and those recently released from prison, people with alcohol and drug addictions, the homeless and the marginalized. Organizations included on the website are working towards trying to keep people out of the criminal justice system by addressing needs rather than viewing them as potential offenders. Maintaining the view that rather than ‘prison works’, freedom works. As well as including projects, there is also a ‘Have your say’ section where, for example, an academic, an ex-probation officer, an ex-prisoner and a practitioner are amongst those who share their views and experiences in 500 words. Works for Freedom is a website that is expanding with new visitors each day to share information and to see what other organizations share the same mission, aims and values. The website can be accessed at: www.worksforfreedom.org

sec.title: Prisoner’s voices: Distance learning for prisoners
sec.p: The new film from Prisoners Education Trust (PET), ’More than Just a Prisoner’, explores the stories of prisoners and ex-prisoners who have changed their social identity and direction in life through learning. ’More than Just a Prisoner’ is a short film featuring the voices of prisoners and ex-prisoners talking about the transformational impact of learning. The film is available online. Viewing of the film can be accessed at: http://www.prisonerseducation.org.uk/index.php?id=578. More information about the background to the film and other work that PET is involved in can be accessed at: www.prisonerseducation.org.uk, or via email: lm@prisonerseducation.org.uk

sec.title: Disclosing previous convictions
sec.p: The Criminal Record Disclosure Calculator (‘the calculator’) is a web tool that can be used to find out when a criminal record becomes spent under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 (ROA). The need to interpret complex legislation means that many people with a criminal record do not benefit from their legal rights under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974, making it harder for them to reintegrate into society. UNLOCK’s new web tool makes it simple to calculate when convictions become ‘spent’ and no longer need to be disclosed to employers and insurers, removing the discrimination which acts as a barrier to successful reintegration. The calculator meets the needs of both individuals and organizations working with people with criminal records. This calculator established when criminal convictions become ‘spent’ under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974. The information collected by this tool is used to provide onscreen results. You also have the option to receive the results by email. Any information provided is not shared with a third party or used by UNLOCK for marketing purposes. Corporate accounts for organizations and professionals who wish to use the Disclosure Calculator can also be set up. For more information on the calculator visit: www.disclosurecalculator.org.uk

sec.title: Guidance for working with learning disabilities and learning difficulties
sec.p: Positive Practice, Positive Outcomes: A Handbook for Professionals in the Criminal Justice System Working with Offenders with a Learning Disability is published by the Department of Health. The handbook provides information, practical advice, signposting and best practice examples for criminal justice professional working with offenders with learning disabilities. The handbook is intended as an introduction to working with offenders with learning disabilities. This group includes police suspects and defendants in court. It covers the essential information to help staff identify and understand this group of people. It covers relevant legislation that outlines the duties and obligations of criminal justice staff, and also health and social care staff, with regards to offenders with learning disabilities. The handbook aims to help criminal justice professionals identify when a person might have learning disabilities, improve their communication with people with learning disabilities, access appropriate support services and be aware of legislation that can help and protect those with learning disabilities and learning difficulties. An online copy of the handbook can be obtained from: http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_124743
